cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
The main international cricket competitions are Test matches, ODI, and which other?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To identify the main international cricket competitions, we need to consider the formats in which international cricket is played. The three primary formats are Test matches, One Day Internationals (ODIs), and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is). Test matches are the longest format, ODIs are limited overs matches played in a single day, and T20Is are a shorter format where each team plays a maximum of 20 overs. Given that the question asks for the third main format alongside Test matches and ODIs, the logical conclusion is that the third format is T20Is.

Answer: Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is)

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
The main international cricket competitions are Test matches, ODI, and which other?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Australian Tri-Series refers to the one day international (ODI) cricket tournament held in Australia, and contested by Australia and two touring teams. The series is played during the height of the Australian cricket season, in the summer months of December, January and February. The series has been the primary format for international one-day cricket throughout most of the history of ODI cricket in Australia. The tri-series was first held in 1979–80 and was contested every season until 2007–08. It has since been held twice, in the 2011–12 season, and again in the 2014–15 season, prior to the World Cup and then the format was switched to Twenty20 International (T20I) format for the first time in the 2017-18 season with Australia, New Zealand and England competing.\n', 'In Test cricket, the Australian team compete for various trophies and championships. The ICC Test Championship is an international competition run by the ICC for the 10 teams that play Test cricket. The competition is notional in the sense that it is simply a ranking scheme overlaid on all international matches that are otherwise played as part of regular Test cricket with no other consideration whatsoever.\n', 'One Day International (ODI) cricket is played between international cricket teams who are Full Members of the International Cricket Council (ICC) as well as the top six Associate and Affiliate members. Unlike Test matches, ODIs consist of one innings per team, having a limit in the number of overs.\n', 'International cricket matches are played between teams representing their nations, normally organised by the International Cricket Council (ICC). The main forms are Test matches, One-Day matches and Twenty20 matches.\n', 'The ICC Test Championship is an international competition run by the International Cricket Council for the 12 teams that play Test cricket. The competition is notional in the sense that it is simply a ranking scheme overlaid on all international matches that are otherwise played as part of regular Test cricket scheduling with no consideration of home or away status.\n', 'The ICC also organises competitions that are for several countries at once, including the Cricket World Cup, ICC T20 World Cup and ICC Champions Trophy. A league competition for Test matches played as part of normal tours, the ICC World Test Championship, has been proposed several times, and is currently planned to begin in 2019. A league competition for ODIs, the 2020–22 ICC Cricket World Cup Super League, is planned to begin in 2020. The ICC maintains Test rankings, ODI rankings and T20 rankings systems for the countries which play these forms of cricket.\n', "The International Cricket Council declared that the matches would count as official One Day Internationals and Test matches. Until recently, ODIs and Test matches had to be played between the teams of two countries. Moreover, the ICC's own rules stipulate that a player can only represent one Test match playing side, and that Test matches are only played between member sides of the ICC, which the 'rest of the world' is not. Some previous matches, such as the series between England and the Rest of the World in 1970, were initially regarded as Test matches but later stripped of Test status by the ICC. At first it was unclear whether the Super Series matches would be recognised as official internationals, but following the decision to recognise the World Cricket Tsunami Appeal match as an official ODI, the ICC decided to award official status to the Super Series matches too. This was the first official Test match not between two countries.\n", 'The ICC World ODI XI was a team chosen by the International Cricket Council (ICC), representing the most talented One Day International cricketers playing international cricket at the time. A One Day International (ODI) is an international cricket match between two representative teams, each having ODI status, as determined by the ICC. An ODI differs from a Test match in that the number of overs per team is limited, and that each team has only one innings. The ICC World XI has played four matches, one for the 2005 World Cricket Tsunami Appeal (where the World XI was made up of the best non-Asian players), and three in the 2005 ICC Super Series (where the World XI was made up of the best non-Australian players). The list is arranged in the order in which each player won his first ODI cap. In cases in which more than one player won his first ODI cap in the same match, these players are listed alphabetically by surname. All these players have represented their respective national teams too, but only the records of their games for the ICC World XI are given.\n', 'Matches played at the highest international and domestic levels are those in which players and/or teams of a recognised high standard are taking part. In modern domestic cricket, it includes first-class cricket, List A cricket and top-class Twenty20 competitions for both men and women. Test cricket, One Day Internationals (ODIs) and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is) are variations of those forms within the international sphere. Historically (see History of cricket), top-class matches were those held by substantial sources to have "historical significance" including single wicket and those double innings matches without statistical significance: i.e., lacking scorecards and other statistical data.\n', "The ICC ODI Championship is an international One Day International (ODI) cricket competition run by the International Cricket Council (ICC). The competition is notional in that it is simply a ranking scheme overlaid on the regular ODI match schedule. After every ODI match, the two teams involved receive points based on a mathematical formula. Each team's points total is divided by their total number of matches played to give a rating, and all the teams are ranked in a table in order of rating.\n"]

3. **Passage 8**: "Test cricket, One Day Internationals (ODIs) and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is) are variations of those forms within the international sphere."

Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To identify the main international cricket competitions, we need to consider the formats in which international cricket is played. The three primary formats are Test matches, One Day Internationals (ODIs), and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is). 

1. **Test Matches**: This is the longest format of the game, traditionally played over five days, where each team has two innings. It is considered the pinnacle of cricket due to its emphasis on endurance, strategy, and skill.

2. **One Day Internationals (ODIs)**: These matches are limited overs contests, where each team plays a maximum of 50 overs. ODIs have become popular for their balance of strategy and excitement, culminating in major tournaments like the Cricket World Cup.

3. **Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is)**: This is the shortest format, where each team plays a maximum of 20 overs. T20 cricket has gained immense popularity due to its fast-paced nature and entertainment value, leading to the establishment of leagues and international tournaments like the ICC T20 World Cup.

Given that the question asks for the third main format alongside Test matches and ODIs, the logical conclusion is that the third format is T20Is. 

Additionally, the passages retrieved provide context about these formats and their significance in international cricket. For instance, they mention that the ICC organizes competitions such as the Cricket World Cup and ICC T20 World Cup, which are pivotal events in the cricket calendar. This highlights the importance of T20Is as a recognized format that has transformed the landscape of international cricket.

### Conclusion

The extracted content from the passages provides a comprehensive understanding of the main international cricket competitions, specifically identifying Test matches, ODIs, and T20Is as the primary formats. This information is crucial for answering the question accurately and for a deeper understanding of the structure of international cricket.

### Answer:
Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is)

Task Description:
Please extract foundational knowledge that may be familiar to the model or advanced information beyond the model's already familiar foundational knowledge from these passages, and analyze the role of these contents.
Summarize and consolidate these contents, which should deepen the model's understanding of the question through familiarity with these basic and advanced pieces of information. 
This process aims to encourage the model to comprehend the question more thoroughly and expand its knowledge boundaries.

To address the question regarding the main international cricket competitions, we can extract and analyze relevant information from the provided passages. The main forms of international cricket mentioned are Test matches, One Day Internationals (ODIs), and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is). 

### Foundational Knowledge Extracted:

1. **Types of International Matches**:
   - **Test Matches**: These are the longest format of cricket, played over five days, where each team has two innings. They are considered the pinnacle of the sport due to their complexity and the skills required.
   - **One Day Internationals (ODIs)**: These matches are limited to 50 overs per side and are played in a single day. They have a more structured format compared to Test matches, with each team batting once.
   - **Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is)**: This is the shortest format, where each team plays a maximum of 20 overs. T20 cricket has gained immense popularity due to its fast-paced nature and entertainment value.

2. **International Cricket Council (ICC)**: The ICC is the governing body for international cricket, responsible for organizing major tournaments and maintaining the rules of the game. It oversees the rankings and competitions for Test matches, ODIs, and T20Is.

3. **Competitions and Championships**:
   - The ICC organizes several major tournaments, including the Cricket World Cup (for ODIs), the ICC T20 World Cup, and the ICC Champions Trophy. These competitions bring together teams from various nations to compete for international titles.
   - The ICC Test Championship is a ranking system for Test matches, while the ICC ODI Championship serves a similar purpose for ODIs.

### Advanced Information:

1. **Historical Context**: The passages mention the evolution of formats, such as the transition from traditional ODIs to T20 formats, indicating a shift in how cricket is played and consumed globally. This reflects changing audience preferences and the commercialization of the sport.

2. **Ranking Systems**: The ICC maintains ranking systems for each format, which are crucial for determining the relative strength of teams and players. These rankings influence tournament seedings and the competitive landscape of international cricket.

3. **Cultural Impact**: The popularity of T20 cricket has led to the establishment of domestic leagues worldwide, further influencing international formats and player participation. This has implications for player availability and the scheduling of international matches.

### Role of the Extracted Content:

The extracted foundational and advanced knowledge serves to deepen the understanding of the question by providing a comprehensive overview of the three main formats of international cricket. Recognizing the distinctions between Test matches, ODIs, and T20Is allows for a clearer understanding of their respective roles in the sport. 

Moreover, understanding the governance by the ICC and the significance of various competitions enhances the context in which these formats operate. This knowledge not only answers the question but also situates it within the broader landscape of international cricket, illustrating how these formats interact with each other and evolve over time.

### Conclusion:

In summary, the main international cricket competitions are Test matches, One Day Internationals (ODIs), and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is). Each format has its unique characteristics, governed by the ICC, and plays a significant role in the global cricketing landscape. This comprehensive understanding enriches the model's knowledge and provides a solid foundation for further exploration of cricket as a sport.

To address the question regarding the main international cricket competitions, we can extract and analyze relevant information from the provided passages. The main forms of international cricket mentioned are Test matches, One Day Internationals (ODIs), and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is). 

### Foundational Knowledge Extracted:

1. **Types of International Matches**:
   - **Test Matches**: These are the longest format of cricket, played over five days, where each team has two innings. They are considered the pinnacle of the sport due to their complexity and the skills required.
   - **One Day Internationals (ODIs)**: These matches are limited to 50 overs per side and are played in a single day. They have a more structured format compared to Test matches, with each team batting once.
   - **Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is)**: This is the shortest format, where each team plays a maximum of 20 overs. T20 cricket has gained immense popularity due to its fast-paced nature and entertainment value.

2. **International Cricket Council (ICC)**: The ICC is the governing body for international cricket, responsible for organizing major tournaments and maintaining the rules of the game. It oversees the rankings and competitions for Test matches, ODIs, and T20Is.

3. **Competitions and Championships**:
   - The ICC organizes several major tournaments, including the Cricket World Cup (for ODIs), the ICC T20 World Cup, and the ICC Champions Trophy. These competitions bring together teams from various nations to compete for international titles.
   - The ICC Test Championship is a ranking system for Test matches, while the ICC ODI Championship serves a similar purpose for ODIs.

### Advanced Information:

1. **Historical Context**: The passages mention the evolution of formats, such as the transition from traditional ODIs to T20 formats, indicating a shift in how cricket is played and consumed globally. This reflects changing audience preferences and the commercialization of the sport.

2. **Ranking Systems**: The ICC maintains ranking systems for each format, which are crucial for determining the relative strength of teams and players. These rankings influence tournament seedings and the competitive landscape of international cricket.

3. **Cultural Impact**: The popularity of T20 cricket has led to the establishment of domestic leagues worldwide, further influencing international formats and player participation. This has implications for player availability and the scheduling of international matches.

### Role of the Extracted Content:

The extracted foundational and advanced knowledge serves to deepen the understanding of the question by providing a comprehensive overview of the three main formats of international cricket. Recognizing the distinctions between Test matches, ODIs, and T20Is allows for a clearer understanding of their respective roles in the sport. 

Moreover, understanding the governance by the ICC and the significance of various competitions enhances the context in which these formats operate. This knowledge not only answers the question but also situates it within the broader landscape of international cricket, illustrating how these formats interact with each other and evolve over time.

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To identify the main international cricket competitions, we need to consider the three primary formats in which international cricket is played: Test matches, One Day Internationals (ODIs), and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is). 

1. **Test Matches**: This format is the longest, traditionally played over five days, allowing each team to bat twice. Test matches are often regarded as the ultimate test of a team's skill, endurance, and strategy, reflecting the rich history and tradition of cricket.

2. **One Day Internationals (ODIs)**: These matches are limited to 50 overs per side and are completed in a single day. They strike a balance between the traditional format and the faster-paced T20 format, making them popular among fans. ODIs have their own prestigious tournaments, such as the Cricket World Cup.

3. **Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is)**: The shortest format, where each team plays a maximum of 20 overs, has rapidly gained popularity due to its fast-paced nature and entertainment value. T20 cricket has transformed the landscape of cricket, leading to the establishment of domestic leagues and a new audience demographic.

The International Cricket Council (ICC) governs these formats and organizes major tournaments, including the ICC Cricket World Cup for ODIs, the ICC T20 World Cup, and the ICC Champions Trophy. The ICC also maintains ranking systems for each format, which are essential for assessing team performance and determining seedings for tournaments.

### Advanced Insights:

- **Evolution of Formats**: The transition from traditional formats to T20 reflects changing audience preferences and the commercialization of the sport. This evolution has implications for how cricket is marketed and consumed globally.
  
- **Cultural Impact**: The rise of T20 cricket has led to the proliferation of domestic leagues, such as the Indian Premier League (IPL), which not only influences player availability for international matches but also impacts the scheduling and format of international competitions.

- **Ranking Systems**: The ICC's ranking systems for Test matches, ODIs, and T20Is provide a framework for evaluating team performance over time, influencing both competitive dynamics and fan engagement.

### Conclusion:

By recognizing the distinctions between Test matches, ODIs, and T20Is, we can appreciate their respective roles in the sport. Each format has unique characteristics and appeals to different segments of the cricketing audience. The governance by the ICC and the significance of various competitions situate these formats within the broader context of international cricket.

### Answer:

The main international cricket competitions are Test matches, One Day Internationals (ODIs), and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is).

In modern domestic cricket, it includes first-class cricket, List A cricket and top-class Twenty20 competitions for both men and women. Test cricket, One Day Internationals (ODIs) and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is) are variations of those forms within the international sphere. Historically (see History of cricket), top-class matches were those held by substantial sources to have "historical significance" including single wicket and those double innings matches without statistical significance: i.e., lacking scorecards and other statistical data.
', "The ICC ODI Championship is an international One Day International (ODI) cricket competition run by the International Cricket Council (ICC). The competition is notional in that it is simply a ranking scheme overlaid on the regular ODI match schedule. After every ODI match, the two teams involved receive points based on a mathematical formula. Each team's points total is divided by their total number of matches played to give a rating, and all the teams are ranked in a table in order of rating.
"]

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages regarding the main international cricket competitions. The key forms of international cricket mentioned are Test matches, One Day Internationals (ODIs), and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is). Here’s a breakdown of the extracted content and its implications for reasoning and inference:

### Extracted Content:

1. **Main Forms of International Cricket**:
   - Test matches
   - One Day Internationals (ODIs)
   - Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is)

2. **Characteristics of Each Format**:
   - **Test Matches**: Played over five days, with two innings per team, allowing for a more strategic and prolonged form of play.
   - **One Day Internationals (ODIs)**: Limited to one innings per team with a set number of overs (usually 50), emphasizing a faster-paced game than Test matches.
   - **Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is)**: The shortest format, with each team playing a single innings of 20 overs, focusing on quick scoring and entertainment.

3. **Organizational Structure**:
   - The International Cricket Council (ICC) oversees these formats, organizing various competitions such as the Cricket World Cup, ICC T20 World Cup, and ICC Champions Trophy.
   - The ICC maintains rankings for each format, which can influence team strategies and player selections.

4. **Historical Context**:
   - The evolution of these formats reflects changes in audience preferences and the commercialization of cricket, leading to the introduction of shorter formats like T20.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

1. **Understanding Relationships**:
   - By identifying the three main formats of international cricket, the model can better understand the relationships between different types of matches and their respective rules, strategies, and audience engagement.
   - This understanding can help in predicting outcomes based on the format being played, such as the likelihood of a team winning based on their historical performance in ODIs versus Test matches.

2. **Causal Inferences**:
   - The model can infer that the introduction of T20 cricket has changed the dynamics of international cricket, leading to shifts in player training, team composition, and fan engagement. This can be used to analyze how changes in one format may affect the others.
   - The ICC's ranking system can be analyzed to infer how a team's performance in one format may impact their ranking and strategies in another format.

3. **Strategic Decision-Making**:
   - Understanding the characteristics of each format allows the model to reason about strategic decisions made by teams, such as when to prioritize certain players for specific formats based on their skills and past performances.
   - The model can also analyze how the scheduling of tournaments influences team preparation and player fitness, leading to better predictions about match outcomes.

4. **Historical Trends and Predictions**:
   - By recognizing historical trends in the evolution of cricket formats, the model can make logical inferences about future developments in the sport, such as potential new formats or changes in existing ones based on audience preferences.

### Conclusion:

The consolidated information from the passages provides a comprehensive view of the main international cricket competitions and their characteristics. This knowledge enhances the model's ability to engage in causal reasoning and logical inference by establishing clear relationships between different cricket formats, their organizational structures, and the implications of historical trends. By leveraging this understanding, the model can make more informed predictions and analyses regarding the sport of cricket.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.
question:

answer:
Reasoning process:

Test matches are the longest format, ODIs are limited overs matches played in a single day, and T20Is are a shorter format where each team plays a maximum of 20 overs. Given that the question asks for the third main format alongside Test matches and ODIs, the logical conclusion is that the third format is T20Is.

Answer: Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is)

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To identify the main international cricket competitions, we begin by recognizing the three primary formats in which international cricket is played: Test matches, One Day Internationals (ODIs), and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is). 

1. **Understanding the Formats**:
   - **Test Matches**: These are the longest format of the game, played over five days, with two innings per team. This format emphasizes strategy, endurance, and skill over a prolonged period.
   - **One Day Internationals (ODIs)**: These matches are limited to one innings per team, with a maximum of 50 overs. ODIs are designed to be completed in a single day, providing a balance between the strategic depth of Test matches and the excitement of shorter formats.
   - **Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is)**: This is the shortest format, where each team plays a single innings of 20 overs. T20Is focus on quick scoring and entertainment, appealing to a broader audience and reflecting the commercialization of the sport.

2. **Organizational Structure**:
   - The International Cricket Council (ICC) governs these formats and organizes major competitions, including the Cricket World Cup, ICC T20 World Cup, and ICC Champions Trophy. The ICC also maintains rankings for each format, which can influence team strategies and player selections.

3. **Causal Relationships**:
   - The introduction of T20 cricket has significantly altered the dynamics of international cricket, leading to changes in player training, team composition, and fan engagement. This evolution illustrates how the emergence of one format can impact the others, as teams adapt their strategies to succeed across different formats.
   - The ICC's ranking system allows for causal inferences regarding how a team's performance in one format may affect their standing and strategies in another format. For example, a team's success in T20s may lead to increased investment in players who excel in that format, potentially affecting their performance in ODIs or Tests.

4. **Strategic Decision-Making**:
   - Understanding the characteristics of each format enables better reasoning about strategic decisions made by teams. For instance, teams may prioritize certain players for specific formats based on their skills and historical performances. Additionally, the scheduling of tournaments can influence team preparation and player fitness, which can be analyzed to predict match outcomes.

5. **Historical Trends and Future Predictions**:
   - Recognizing historical trends in the evolution of cricket formats allows for logical inferences about future developments in the sport. For example, as audience preferences shift, new formats may emerge, or existing formats may undergo changes to maintain viewer engagement.

### Conclusion:
The consolidated knowledge about the main international cricket competitions and their characteristics enhances the model's ability to engage in causal reasoning and logical inference. By establishing clear relationships between different cricket formats, their organizational structures, and the implications of historical trends, the model can make more informed predictions and analyses regarding the sport of cricket.

### Answer:
The third main international cricket competition, alongside Test matches and One Day Internationals (ODIs), is Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is).

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
The main international cricket competitions are Test matches, ODI, and which other?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Australian Tri-Series refers to the one day international (ODI) cricket tournament held in Australia, and contested by Australia and two touring teams. The series is played during the height of the Australian cricket season, in the summer months of December, January and February. The series has been the primary format for international one-day cricket throughout most of the history of ODI cricket in Australia. The tri-series was first held in 1979–80 and was contested every season until 2007–08. It has since been held twice, in the 2011–12 season, and again in the 2014–15 season, prior to the World Cup and then the format was switched to Twenty20 International (T20I) format for the first time in the 2017-18 season with Australia, New Zealand and England competing.\n', 'In Test cricket, the Australian team compete for various trophies and championships. The ICC Test Championship is an international competition run by the ICC for the 10 teams that play Test cricket. The competition is notional in the sense that it is simply a ranking scheme overlaid on all international matches that are otherwise played as part of regular Test cricket with no other consideration whatsoever.\n', 'One Day International (ODI) cricket is played between international cricket teams who are Full Members of the International Cricket Council (ICC) as well as the top six Associate and Affiliate members. Unlike Test matches, ODIs consist of one innings per team, having a limit in the number of overs.\n', 'International cricket matches are played between teams representing their nations, normally organised by the International Cricket Council (ICC). The main forms are Test matches, One-Day matches and Twenty20 matches.\n', 'The ICC Test Championship is an international competition run by the International Cricket Council for the 12 teams that play Test cricket. The competition is notional in the sense that it is simply a ranking scheme overlaid on all international matches that are otherwise played as part of regular Test cricket scheduling with no consideration of home or away status.\n', 'The ICC also organises competitions that are for several countries at once, including the Cricket World Cup, ICC T20 World Cup and ICC Champions Trophy. A league competition for Test matches played as part of normal tours, the ICC World Test Championship, has been proposed several times, and is currently planned to begin in 2019. A league competition for ODIs, the 2020–22 ICC Cricket World Cup Super League, is planned to begin in 2020. The ICC maintains Test rankings, ODI rankings and T20 rankings systems for the countries which play these forms of cricket.\n', "The International Cricket Council declared that the matches would count as official One Day Internationals and Test matches. Until recently, ODIs and Test matches had to be played between the teams of two countries. Moreover, the ICC's own rules stipulate that a player can only represent one Test match playing side, and that Test matches are only played between member sides of the ICC, which the 'rest of the world' is not. Some previous matches, such as the series between England and the Rest of the World in 1970, were initially regarded as Test matches but later stripped of Test status by the ICC. At first it was unclear whether the Super Series matches would be recognised as official internationals, but following the decision to recognise the World Cricket Tsunami Appeal match as an official ODI, the ICC decided to award official status to the Super Series matches too. This was the first official Test match not between two countries.\n", 'The ICC World ODI XI was a team chosen by the International Cricket Council (ICC), representing the most talented One Day International cricketers playing international cricket at the time. A One Day International (ODI) is an international cricket match between two representative teams, each having ODI status, as determined by the ICC. An ODI differs from a Test match in that the number of overs per team is limited, and that each team has only one innings. The ICC World XI has played four matches, one for the 2005 World Cricket Tsunami Appeal (where the World XI was made up of the best non-Asian players), and three in the 2005 ICC Super Series (where the World XI was made up of the best non-Australian players). The list is arranged in the order in which each player won his first ODI cap. In cases in which more than one player won his first ODI cap in the same match, these players are listed alphabetically by surname. All these players have represented their respective national teams too, but only the records of their games for the ICC World XI are given.\n', 'Matches played at the highest international and domestic levels are those in which players and/or teams of a recognised high standard are taking part. In modern domestic cricket, it includes first-class cricket, List A cricket and top-class Twenty20 competitions for both men and women. Test cricket, One Day Internationals (ODIs) and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is) are variations of those forms within the international sphere. Historically (see History of cricket), top-class matches were those held by substantial sources to have "historical significance" including single wicket and those double innings matches without statistical significance: i.e., lacking scorecards and other statistical data.\n', "The ICC ODI Championship is an international One Day International (ODI) cricket competition run by the International Cricket Council (ICC). The competition is notional in that it is simply a ranking scheme overlaid on the regular ODI match schedule. After every ODI match, the two teams involved receive points based on a mathematical formula. Each team's points total is divided by their total number of matches played to give a rating, and all the teams are ranked in a table in order of rating.\n"]

To identify the main international cricket competitions, we need to consider the formats in which international cricket is played. The three primary formats are Test matches, One Day Internationals (ODIs), and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is). 

1. **Understanding the Formats**: 
   - Test matches are the longest format of the game, typically lasting up to five days, where each team has two innings.
   - ODIs are limited overs matches played in a single day, where each team has a maximum of 50 overs.
   - T20Is are a shorter format where each team plays a maximum of 20 overs, making it a fast-paced and exciting version of the game.

2. **Confirmation from Retrieved Knowledge**:

The main forms are Test matches, One-Day matches and Twenty20 matches."

3. **Recognition of T20 as a Major Format**: 
   The passages indicate that T20Is are recognized as a major format of international cricket, which is crucial for understanding the hierarchy of cricket formats. The passage states: "Test cricket, One Day Internationals (ODIs) and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is) are variations of those forms within the international sphere."

4. **ICC Competitions**: 
   The significance of T20 cricket is further established by mentioning various ICC-organized competitions, including the ICC T20 World Cup. This highlights the importance of T20Is in the international cricket landscape, as noted in the passage: "The ICC also organises competitions that are for several countries at once, including the Cricket World Cup, ICC T20 World Cup and ICC Champions Trophy."

Given this comprehensive understanding, it is clear that the third main format of international cricket, alongside Test matches and ODIs, is T20Is.

**Answer**: Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is)

question_info.question: The main international cricket competitions are Test matches, ODI, and which other?
passages:
The Australian Tri-Series refers to the one day international (ODI) cricket tournament held in Australia, and contested by Australia and two touring teams. The series is played during the height of the Australian cricket season, in the summer months of December, January and February. The series has been the primary format for international one-day cricket throughout most of the history of ODI cricket in Australia. The tri-series was first held in 1979–80 and was contested every season until 2007–08. It has since been held twice, in the 2011–12 season, and again in the 2014–15 season, prior to the World Cup and then the format was switched to Twenty20 International (T20I) format for the first time in the 2017-18 season with Australia, New Zealand and England competing.
In Test cricket, the Australian team compete for various trophies and championships. The ICC Test Championship is an international competition run by the ICC for the 10 teams that play Test cricket. The competition is notional in the sense that it is simply a ranking scheme overlaid on all international matches that are otherwise played as part of regular Test cricket with no other consideration whatsoever.
One Day International (ODI) cricket is played between international cricket teams who are Full Members of the International Cricket Council (ICC) as well as the top six Associate and Affiliate members. Unlike Test matches, ODIs consist of one innings per team, having a limit in the number of overs.
International cricket matches are played between teams representing their nations, normally organised by the International Cricket Council (ICC). The main forms are Test matches, One-Day matches and Twenty20 matches.
The ICC Test Championship is an international competition run by the International Cricket Council for the 12 teams that play Test cricket. The competition is notional in the sense that it is simply a ranking scheme overlaid on all international matches that are otherwise played as part of regular Test cricket scheduling with no consideration of home or away status.
The ICC also organises competitions that are for several countries at once, including the Cricket World Cup, ICC T20 World Cup and ICC Champions Trophy. A league competition for Test matches played as part of normal tours, the ICC World Test Championship, has been proposed several times, and is currently planned to begin in 2019. A league competition for ODIs, the 2020–22 ICC Cricket World Cup Super League, is planned to begin in 2020. The ICC maintains Test rankings, ODI rankings and T20 rankings systems for the countries which play these forms of cricket.
The International Cricket Council declared that the matches would count as official One Day Internationals and Test matches. Until recently, ODIs and Test matches had to be played between the teams of two countries. Moreover, the ICC's own rules stipulate that a player can only represent one Test match playing side, and that Test matches are only played between member sides of the ICC, which the 'rest of the world' is not. Some previous matches, such as the series between England and the Rest of the World in 1970, were initially regarded as Test matches but later stripped of Test status by the ICC. At first it was unclear whether the Super Series matches would be recognised as official internationals, but following the decision to recognise the World Cricket Tsunami Appeal match as an official ODI, the ICC decided to award official status to the Super Series matches too. This was the first official Test match not between two countries.
The ICC World ODI XI was a team chosen by the International Cricket Council (ICC), representing the most talented One Day International cricketers playing international cricket at the time. A One Day International (ODI) is an international cricket match between two representative teams, each having ODI status, as determined by the ICC. An ODI differs from a Test match in that the number of overs per team is limited, and that each team has only one innings. The ICC World XI has played four matches, one for the 2005 World Cricket Tsunami Appeal (where the World XI was made up of the best non-Asian players), and three in the 2005 ICC Super Series (where the World XI was made up of the best non-Australian players). The list is arranged in the order in which each player won his first ODI cap. In cases in which more than one player won his first ODI cap in the same match, these players are listed alphabetically by surname. All these players have represented their respective national teams too, but only the records of their games for the ICC World XI are given.
Matches played at the highest international and domestic levels are those in which players and/or teams of a recognised high standard are taking part. In modern domestic cricket, it includes first-class cricket, List A cricket and top-class Twenty20 competitions for both men and women. Test cricket, One Day Internationals (ODIs) and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is) are variations of those forms within the international sphere. Historically (see History of cricket), top-class matches were those held by substantial sources to have "historical significance" including single wicket and those double innings matches without statistical significance: i.e., lacking scorecards and other statistical data.
The ICC ODI Championship is an international One Day International (ODI) cricket competition run by the International Cricket Council (ICC). The competition is notional in that it is simply a ranking scheme overlaid on the regular ODI match schedule. After every ODI match, the two teams involved receive points based on a mathematical formula. Each team's points total is divided by their total number of matches played to give a rating, and all the teams are ranked in a table in order of rating.
